coref_content: corporate hospitality spending be already up 12.4 per cent on last year show you ca nt keep corporate Australia away from corporate Australia's favourite party of the year. share price have tumble, the jobless rate have top 6 per cent and the mining boom be a distant spike in Gina Rineharts bank balance. but you still ca nt nt keep corporate Australia away from its favourite party of the year. the largesse on offer at the Melbourne Cup usually provide a good barometer of the mood of corporate Australia. in the wake of the GFC, the cutback be palpable. then Myer boss Bernie Brookes make Myer boss Bernie Brookes's executive team swap a fleet of private limo for a bus back to Myer. Emirates slash spending from almost $ 1500 a head to less than four figure. the Packer family private fund Ellerston pull out of the Birdcage altogether. but tough time in the economy ca nt keep the corporate away this year. in fact, just over a month out, sale have soar. the Victoria Racing Club say corporate hospitality spending be already up 12.4 per cent on last year. big gain have come from Emirates Cup Day and Crown Stakes day. we be just 33 day out from AAMI Victoria Derby Day and there s every indication be in for a big carnival, say the Victoria Racing Club chief executive Simon Love. sale be up across the board, with corporate hospitality up more than 12 per cent up on this time last year. global drink company Diageo be the only big player to withdraw from the Birdcage this year, with no Johnnie Walker marquee this year but Johnnie Walker marquee have quickly be snap up by radio giant Southern Cross Austereo. one in, one out and everyone fully expect global drink company Diageo back next year, say one racing industry insider. punter ticket sale soar too ticket sale have also soar, after a couple of quiet carnival. with soar come the big fashion spend. in each of the last two carnival, spending have be stagnant, with $ 31.4 million of attribute victorian sale on fashion item specifically to wear to Flemington. $ 31.4 million of attribute victorian sale on fashion item specifically to wear to Flemington include an estimate 5000 hat and fascinator, 61,000 dress, 59,000 pair of shoe and 30,000 handbag. man be spend big, too, with 17,000 shirt and 15,000 suit sell for the carnival last year. the data show the sale do nt all go to big marketer, such as Myer, but also benefit small boutique, milliner and shop. indeed, while Myer battle through tough time at the till, high - end Melbourne tailor Oscar Hunt have do so well a Sydney store be open last week. who say brick and mortar retail be dead southern - most charter among 50 country the overseas raid on this year now expand beyond the actual racetrack. on Saturday, 10 European - train horse arrive in Melbourne and go into quarantine. but the Victoria Racing Club be expect visitor in Melbourne from almost 50 different country, up from 43 last year. visitor in Melbourne from almost 50 different country, up from 43 last year do come with a warning. visitor in Melbourne from almost 50 different country, up from 43 last year include the first ever international passenger flight out of New Zealands southernmost city, Invercargill, and a place that be the butt of many a joke across the ditch. apparently the only other overseas destination you can get to from Invercargill Airport be Antarctica, as long as you be happy to stay for six month on a scientific expedition. the planeload of 180 Kiwi racing fan be actually a little brave - the planeload of 180 Kiwi racing fan have charter the flight to the Melbourne Cup as a day trip. the HECKLER it a bird. it a plane. its the Fiat Chrysler Flying Circus. big shout out to some regional plane spotter, who jot down detail of the Alfa Romeo aircraft allegedly pay for by Fiat Chrysler barnstorm near Mount Buffalo Airport on Friday afternoon. we be nt sure if the pilot and passenger be hole up at luxury retreat Villa Gusto, or the Freeburgh property own by the car company embattle former boss Clyde Campbell. but it nice to know the fly billboard be be notice. the story first appear on the Sydney Morning Herald ..
